document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy of ' Euconnus complex'. Part III. Morphology of Euconnus subgenus Napochus and revision of the Australian species (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomy of ' Euconnus complex'. Part III. Morphology of Euconnus subgenus Napochus and revision of the Australian species (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae)

heading.emphasis:
Morphology of
Euconnus claviger (Müller & Kunze)
, the type species of
Euconnus ( Napochus )

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2. General morphology of
Euconnus ( Napochus ) claviger (Müller & Kunze)
, the type species of
Napochus
, in dorsal (1) and lateral (2) views.

FIGURES 3–6. Details of morphology of
Euconnus ( Napochus ) claviger (Müller & Kunze)
. Head in anterodorsal (3) and ventral (5) views, mouthparts in anterodorsal (4) and ventral (6) views. Abbreviations: bst, basistipes; cd, cardo; cl, clypeus; fcg, frontoclypeal groove; fo, foramen occipitale; fr, frons; gal, galea, gp, gular plate; gs, gular suture; hr, hypostomal ridge; lb, labrum; lig, ligula; lp, labial palp; md, mandible; mn, mentum; mse, median sensillum of epipharynx; mst, mediostipes; mxp, maxillary palp; ptp, posterior tentorial pit; smn, submentum; vt, vertex.

FIGURES 7–10. Details of morphology of
Euconnus ( Napochus ) claviger (Müller & Kunze)
. Prothorax in dorsal (7, 8) and ventral (9) views, mesonotum in dorsal view (10). Abbreviations: bst, basisternal part of prosternum; hy, hypomeron; hyr, hypomeral ridge; lap, lateral antebasal pit; nss, pronotosternal suture; pcc, procoxal cavity; pcs, procoxal socket; pff, profurcal fovea; psp, prosternal process; sc2, mesoscutm; scl2, mesoscutellum; slc, sublateral carina of pronotum; sss, mesoscutoscutellar suture.

FIGURES 11–13. Details of morphology of
Euconnus ( Napochus ) claviger (Müller & Kunze)
. Pterothorax and abdomen in ventral view (11), mesothorax in ventral view (12), posteromedian part of metathorax and base of abdomen in ventral view (13). Abbreviations: anterior ridge; cx3, metacoxa; epm3, metepimeron; mscc, mesocoxal cavity; mscs, mesocoxal socket; mcp, mesocoxal projection; msff, mesofurcal fovea; msvp, mesoventral intercoxal process; mtvp, metaventral intercoxal process; pcr, procoxal rest; pre, prepectus; tr3, metatrochanter; v3, metaventrite.

FIGURES 14–17. Details of morphology of
Euconnus ( Napochus ) claviger (Müller & Kunze)
. Metanotum in dorsal view (14, 15), pterothorax in left lateral view (16), mesoventral intercoxal process in left lateral view (17). Abbreviations: aest2, mesanepisternum; aest3, metanepisternum; alc, alacrista; apo, apodeme; cx3, metacoxa; dlf, dorsolateral fovea; epm2, mesepimeron; epm3, metepimeron; mma, median membranous area; msvp, mesoventral intercoxal process; pre, prepectus; prsc3, metaprescutum; psn3, metapostnotum; sc3, metascutum; scl3, metascutellum; v2, mesoventrite; v3, metaventrite.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Elytra (
Figs. 1 –2
, 19 ) oval, with rounded apices; humeral denticle absent; humeral callus moderately distinct, delimited from adsutural region by shallow basal impression; subhumeral line absent; elytral base with two distinct, circular and asetose basal foveae (
Fig. 19
; bef ); elytral disc sparsely covered with long, curved and suberect setae.

Metathoracic wings about twice as long as elytra, with posterior margin bearing dense fringe of long setae; venation highly reduced and with few indistinct veins visible only in basal part of wing, homology difficult to interpret.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 18–23. Details of morphology of
Euconnus
(
Napochus
)
claviger
(Müller & Kunze)
. Meso- and metaventrite, dorsal view (18), elytral base in dorsal view (19), abdomen in ventral view (20), propygidium and pygidium in dorsal view (21), surface of propygidium and pygidium in dorsal view (22), aedeagus in ventral view (23). Abbreviations: bef, basal elytral fovea; bo, basal orifice; cxl, coxal line; dap, dorsal apical projection; ilp, internal lateral projection; lmfa, lateral metafurcal arm; mtcc, metacoxal cavity; mtfs, metafurcal stem; pf, porous field; pg, pygidium; pm, paramere; prpg, propygidium; s, scale-like sculpture; st3–8, abdominal sternites 3–8; v2, mesoventrite; v3, metaventrite; vap, ventral apical projection; vw, ventral wall.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Several structures, previously described in detail for
Euconnus
s. str. (
Jałoszyński 2012 a
), were omitted from illustrations and descriptions presented here. The reason was the small number of specimens available for dissections, and therefore some structures remained hidden when others were exposed and documented by SEM, and some others were partly damaged during disarticulations. However, some of such structures, even if not possible to visualize in photographs suitable for publication, were examined, and the female ovipositor, spermatheca, and male terminalia were found to be similar (i.e., not substantially different in general structure) to those of
Euconnus
s. str.

Examination of the Australian species revealed that there are two pairs of lateral projections of the endophallus. The internal pair is always more distinct in the specimens studied, usually also larger and darker than the external lateral projections. The latter are lightly pigmented and may be obscured by the internal pair or are indiscernible in all or some specimens. In
Euconnus claviger
only one pair of lateral projections was found, and they are dark and distinct (
Fig. 23
). Therefore, they are here interpreted as internal lateral projections and the external pair in the type species of
Napochus
may be concealed by large internal projections, being indiscernible in transparent preparations or are missing. Aedeagi of the Australian species show distinct similarities in structure to the copulatory organ of
E. claviger
; they all have flattened ventral and dorsal apical projections, lateral projections, and symmetrical dark median components of endophallus. The slightly asymmetrical median component of the endophallus visible in the studied specimen of
E. claviger
(
Fig. 23
) seems to be dislocated. In many specimens studied at various times by me this structure was found to be quite variable and prone to distortion.
